target_markets.market_description: Broke individuals who want to build wealth, particularly young professionals and minimum wage workers
demographics: minimum wage to median income earners
pain_points: high debt burden (35% of income to debt)
target_markets.market_size_indicators: Average American has negative net worth, minimum wage workers earn $1M+ lifetime, median income earners make $3M lifetime

problems_validated.problem: Americans spending 35% of paycheck on debt payments to banks and lenders
problems_validated.severity: Critical - prevents wealth building and keeps people in poverty cycle
problems_validated.current_solutions: People try to get 9-10% stock market returns while paying 24% credit card interest
problems_validated.market_gap: People don't understand debt as guaranteed negative returns vs uncertain positive investment returns

products_tools.name: S&P 500 Index Investment
products_tools.use_case: Long-term wealth building through compound interest

business_strategies.strategy: Maintain extremely low personal expenses to enable high business risk-taking
business_strategies.implementation: Live on minimal expenses even when earning high income (lived on <$15K/month while making $1M/month)
business_strategies.expected_results: Ability to take multiple business risks and recover from failures
business_strategies.case_study: Speaker failed 9 businesses and 7 partnerships but could restart because of low personal expenses

problems_solutions.problem: Being broke despite earning sufficient income
problems_solutions.solution: Six-step wealth building process starting with buy-nothing challenge
tools_needed: Disconnect credit cards from online shopping

mistakes_to_avoid.mistake: Paying credit card interest (24%) while trying to earn stock market returns (9-10%)
mistakes_to_avoid.consequences: Guaranteed negative returns that compound against wealth building
mistakes_to_avoid.prevention: Pay off all high-interest debt before investing
mistakes_to_avoid.example: People fighting against compound interest (8th Wonder of the World) instead of using it

mistakes_to_avoid.consequences: Prevents capital accumulation needed for business opportunities
mistakes_to_avoid.prevention: Maintain low expenses regardless of income level
mistakes_to_avoid.example: Speaker kept $1,200/month rent even when making $1M/month

metrics_kpis.benchmark: What you earn divided by what you need - maximize the gap
metrics_kpis.optimization_tip: Focus more on reducing expenses than increasing income initially

trends_signals.trend: Average Americans have negative net worth
trends_signals.opportunity: Massive market for financial education and wealth-building services

actionable_quotes.quote: wealth is actually a ratio between what you earn and what you need
actionable_quotes.context: Explaining why expense control is more important than income maximization initially
actionable_quotes.actionability: Focus on reducing needs/expenses rather than just increasing income

actionable_quotes.quote: the number one rule of money is spend less than you make
actionable_quotes.actionability: Audit all expenses and eliminate non-essential spending

actionable_quotes.quote: you will increase your shots on goal by living risk-free or low risk in your personal life
actionable_quotes.context: Explaining how low personal expenses enable business risk-taking
actionable_quotes.actionability: Minimize personal financial obligations to enable entrepreneurial opportunities

key_statistics.statistic: Average American has literal negative net worth
key_statistics.context: Babies are richer than adults because babies haven't gone into debt

key_statistics.statistic: Average US minimum wage employee will make over $1 million in lifetime earnings
key_statistics.context: Median income earners make $3 million over their lifetime

key_statistics.statistic: 35% of every paycheck goes towards paying banks and lenders for debt
key_statistics.context: Including mortgage, car payments, and credit cards

key_statistics.statistic: $200 invested in S&P 500 at age 25 becomes $6,000+ by age 65
key_statistics.context: 9% annual return over 40 years demonstrates compound interest power
